Input Shortcut

Input shortcut can be used in lots of places in order to see the options you have available. If you changed it in settings and have forgotten it, don't worry! You can input sc-inputshortcut to find out what it is set to. You can also change it in settings ('set/'settings' when in the main menu) to one of a small selection keys.

Super commands

Super commands are text commands that can be used anywhere, usually to enhance your experience. Below are a list of the current super commands:


---------SUPER COMMAND LIST---------

sc-[element]-[number]px to change the text size of a box; Possible inputs for [element] are "main", "stat" and "misc" For example "sc-main-20px" will change the size of text in the main box (big output box) to 20 pixels

sc-reset to reset the sizes of all boxes. Default size is 16 px

sc-volume-NUMBER to change game volume. NUMBER must be between 0 (mute) and 1 (max volume)
sc-music-NUMBER to change music volume and not FX
sc-fx-NUMBER to change FX volume and not music

sc-minimap to toggle minimap display where applicable [this can be used in some places where 'sm'/'show minimap' cannot, like battle and the inventory]

sc-clear to clear the main view (This will wipe all text from the display, so ensure you know where you are menuwise if you're going to do this.)

sc-return to immediately exit applicable menus (crafting, shop, stats, inventory) no matter where you are (no need to input 'b'/'back' several times)

sc-inputshortcut to see your designated input shortcut key.

sc-discord to bring up a message showing the TRPG discord invite link.

sc-help (obviously!) To open the help module and sc-helpreset to reset its position when it is moved offscreen

Combat - Stats

There are quite a few stats, but don't worrys since most of them are self-explanatory. Regardless, this sections will go over them in detail:

Attack and Magic Attack dictate damage dealt by your physical and magical attacks. Similarly, Defence and Magic Defence dictate the amount by which incoming physical and magical attacks are reduced. (DO NOTE that 'physical' the element (along with fire, water, etc..) and 'physical' the attack type ('physical and magical') are two VERY different things. Attack boosts physical damage, the ATTACK TYPE. To increase the damage of attacks with the physical ELEMENT, you need to increase your physical offence stat [the elemental stat]).

Speed is a special stat. If your speed is at least 2x as high as your opponent's, you will gain an additional action on your turns!

Stamina, Mana and SP are used to perform certain skills. Stamina regenerates over time during a battle, whereas Mana does not. SP always starts at 0 and is usually gained through certain skill and item effects. Keep in mind that stamina, health and mana will not regenerate inbetween battles while exploring!

Effectiveness increases your chances of applying a debuff by a certain percentage. Resistance decreases your chances of applying a debuff by a certain percentage.

Your Elemental stats show the percentages of damage you take/deal from certain elements. 200 fire attack means your fire attacks deal double (200%) damage, and 50 fire defence means fire attacks dealt to you deal half (50%) damage. The percentage you see beside a number when an attack is used is a combination of the user's elemental offence, the target's elemental defence and any mitigation effects. Elemental stats cannot go below 1 or above 500.

Evasion refers to the percentage chance of evading an attack. This starts at 0 for a player, but can be raised using skills and equipment. If an attack is evaded, no damage will be taken and sometimes effects (such as debuffs) will not occur. Generally speaking, only attacks that deal damage can be evaded.

Critical chance refers to a percentage chance of dealing a critical attack, in which case the attack will deal a percentage of the original damage denoted by your Critical damage (original damage is 100%, so with a critical damage of 150%, a critical hit will cause your attack to deal 1.5x damage).

The Buff limit for Attack, Magic Attack, Defence, Magic Defence and Speed is up to 500% (all buffs stack additively).

There is no such cap for Critical chance/damage, Resistance, Effectiveness or Evasion, however they cannot go below 0. Damage dealt cannot be negative.

Combat - Options

Most of the options in combat will be your skills. But there are a few besides them that need to be known:

First of all, you can use Input Shortcut during battle to check your options. This is strongly recommended as you may forget the skills that you have equipped/their exact names. Make good use of input shortcut during combat.

Input Skills to see the names and descriptions (which will include cost and effects) of all your skills.

Input Status to see all buffs and debuffs applied to your character, along with your current HP, Mana, Stamina and SP (however these can also be viewed via the display in the upper right)

Input Enemy to see all buffs and debuffs applied to the enemy, along with their HP, Mana, Stamina and SP. You may want to keep track of your enemies' resources to see when/if they can use certain skills, and possibly also to deduce the costs of some of their skills.

Input Flee to immediately end the battle. However if you do so, it will automatically result in your loss. There is no death penalty in TRPG, however you will return to the main menu and have to return to your position while exploring manually and/or redo the fight. It is recommended only to use this if your defeat is imminent.

Combat - Damage

Dealing damage, as you might expect, is the key to victory. When you deal damage, you will see something like this:

Pel struck the enemy! [Attack]
10 damage! (100% physical) [physical]

On the first line, Pel struck the enemy! is the action description of the skill. Most skills will have their own unique action description, but it doesn't really mean anything. In square brackets beside the action description is the name of the skill [Attack]

On the second line, (100% physical) shows the damage type, along with the percentage modifier applied to the damage. This is combination of your elemenal offence, the enemy's elemental defence, and their mitigation. It does not take into account critical damage or any other modifiers. If you know your elemental offence and the enemy's mitigation, you can use this to infer their elemental defence for that element. But it is probably best just to use Check on them.

In square brackets beside this, [physical] is the attack element. Note here how this is a PHYSICAL type attack of the PHYSICAL element. This means it uses the stat defence and the elemental stat physical defence. A skill with the line
10 damage! (100% physical) [water]
deals physical (type) water (element) damage, and a skill with the line
10 damage! (100% magical) [physical]
deals magical (type) physical (element) damage, although this would be quite rare.
Damage is also coloured according to the element, but if you have something like a dark theme web extension, the colouring can be messed up. This will ensure you know the elements of the attacks you are struck by and use.

Skills and SP - Disciplines

Skills are organised into Disciplines. They usually follow a specific theme or specific strategy, but the skills within can be mixed with other disciplines for an optimal setup. Unlocking a discipline and also unlocking each individual skill within a discipline will each incur a cost. Disciplines cannot be 'forgotten' like skills can, but the resources needed to unlock them are not level-locked like AP is for skills. Disciplines may become visible as you grow stronger or complete other tasks. Currently, there are 4 disciplines ingame.

Skills and SP - Learning and forgetting skills

You can learn skills that are in disciplines you've unlocked in order to add them to your repertoire (you have to equip them first to use them in battle though). To learn a skill, use the following inputs (from the main stats menu):

'sk'/'skills' -> 'l'/'learn' -> Select the desired discipline -> Select the desired skill -> If it can be learned, you will be given the option to do so.


Most skills can also be forgotten. This will return the AP from having learned the skill, but nothing else - the gold and any reagents used will be lost forever. A skill must not be equipped if you are to forget it. To forget a skill, use the following inputs (from the main stats menu):

'sk'/'skills' -> 'e'/'equipped' -> Select the discipline of the skill -> 'f'/'forget' -> Confirm decision

Skills and SP - Equipping and unequipping skills

After you've unlocked a skill, in order to use it in combat, you need to have it equipped. You can have up to 12 skills equipped, including 'Attack' and 'Guard'. They cannot be unequipped, which means you can have 10 skills of your choice equipped at any one time. There is no restriction on the combinations of skills you can have equipped. To equip a skill, use the following inputs (from the main stats menu):

'sk'/'skills' -> 'e'/'equipped' -> Select the appropriate discipline -> Select the appropriate skill -> 'e'/'equip'


You can also view all your currently equipped skills. When doing so, you can type the name of an equipped skill in order to unequip it. To do both of these things, use the following inputs (from the main stats menu):

'sk'/'skills' -> 'e'/'equipped' -> 'e'/'equipped'

Skills and SP - Allocating SP

When you level up, all your stats increase slightly. However, you will also gain two SP, which you can use to further increase certain stats of your choice. The following stats can be allocated to:

Health - 20 HP per 1 SP
Mana - 15 Mana per 1 SP
Atk, Def, MAtk, MDef, Speed - 2 of each stat per 1 SP

Do note that there is a limit to the amount of SP that can be allocated to one stat depending on your level. This is to prevent overly min-maxed builds.

SP can also be reset. Specific stats cannot be un-allocated, only all allocated SP at once. This incurs a gold cost, which is equal to the total SP allocated * 20.

The SP menu is easy to find. To access it, just input 'sp' in the main stats menu.

General Assistance - FAQ

I'm stuck in a menu!
Firstly, if you just want to navigate backwards, usually 'b'/'back' will do the trick. When exploring, input 'rep'/'reprint' to see your options.
Usually, to remedy this, you can press the allocated input shortcut key. You can use the super command 'sc-inputshortcut' to check what your toggle for it is. If input shortcut is unavailable, you can try to scroll up and see if there were any instructions for the menu you're in.

As a side note, if input shorcut won't work and 'back' won't work, you are probably exploring. So input 'rep'/'reprint' to see your options. You may also find that 'sc-return' brings you to a menu you can operate in.

General Assistance - Game tips

I can't beat an enemy!
Enemies will often have gimmicks or behaviours that, when understood make the fight significantly easier. Try to look for patterns such as the turns that skills are used, or the costs of some skills and when they are used. Some enemies will respond to your actions by using certain skills, others will use a skill whenever available, for others, it may be random. Watch out for Boost in particular; some monsters will use it whenever they have the SP.

Alternatively, try Analyzing the enemy using the skill in the Adventurer's discipline. This way you can learn of any potential weaknesses, and perhaps infer some things about its behaviour from your observations. You can also try and change your stats to suit certain enemies, for example having just enough speed to gain the extra action. Find the strategy that best suits you!

Also, while battling, keep in mind small plays that are slightly more efficient - they may help in the long run. An example is guarding when you know an enemy is going to boost. This will reduce the damage they deal boosting, and you can use the gained SP to boost yourself and deal additional (unguarded) damage. In this case, their use of SP was less efficient than yours, and this can be the difference between victory and defeat.


I keep dying while travelling!
It could help to learn about the enemies in the area, so you can beat them efficiently and not have to use as many items. Also, many floor shops (accesible in the main menu by inputting 'shop') will sell items like health and mana potions to help you explore more easily. You can sell enemy drops to get gold fast for potions and the like.
